title: 0 Introduction
text: massive amounts data sensors, usually recorded high temporal resolution (every second) challenging data processing visualisation. Especially standard tools like MS EXCEL used, well suited tasks data import restrictions (e.g. rows per spreadsheet limited maximum 1 million rows MS EXCEL 2010) missing built-features data aggregation (e.g. calculating one hour median values raw data). addition operational data often needs combined analytical data (usually temporal resolution days weeks) example order (1) assess impact plant’s operation scheme (e.g. flow rate) performance reducing specific substances (2) calculating substance loads (multiplying substance concentrations flow rates) Within AQUANES project – order address challenges small companies wa-ter operators – data visualization reporting tool developed software R (www.r-project.org), enables user : - Explore online offline data different temporal aggregation levels (e.g. raw data 10 minutes median values) - Create automated reports including raw (online/offline) data also advanced calculations combining different online /offline data (e.g. specific en-ergy demand) first step, R reporting tool implemented tested AQUANES site Haridwar, described report.

Miktex: needs installed case pdf reports created. advanced user recommended install latest version integrated development environment (IDE) RStudio Desktop “open source licence”.

title: Pilot: Ultimate
code: ################################################################################ ### 1. Write Pilot Plant Raw Data to InfluxDB Cloud ################################################################################  ################################################################################ ### 1.1 Pilot A ################################################################################  ## Step: kwb.pilot::download_nextcloud_files() is optional and can be skipped ## if the data is provided in the `paths$raw_data_dir` files_pilot_a <- kwb.pilot::download_nextcloud_files(   dir_cloud = paths$a_cloud_raw,   dir_local = paths$a_local_raw )  if (length(files_pilot_a) > 0L) {      tsv_paths <- list.files(     path = paths$a_local_raw,     full.names = TRUE,     pattern = "xls$"   )      kwb.pilot::write_to_influxdb_loop(     tsv_paths = tsv_paths,     paths = list(       site_code = paths$a_site_code,       raw_data_dir = paths$a_local_raw     ),     changed_only = FALSE,     max_tsv_files = 10,     batch_size = 5000   )      ### Move all files for Pilot A`s cloud "raw" data directory to the "imported"    ### directory (in case that a file is already existing there: overwrite it)!   paths_pilot_a <- data.frame(     raw = file.path(paths$a_cloud_raw, files_pilot_a),     imported = file.path(paths$a_cloud_imported, files_pilot_a     )   )      kwb.pilot::move_nextcloud_files(paths_pilot_a, overwrite = TRUE)    } else {      message(sprintf(     "Nothing to do for '%s'! No new files in '%s'",     paths$a_site_code,     paths$a_cloud_raw   )) } ################################################################################ ### 1.2 Pilot B ################################################################################  ## Step: kwb.pilot::download_nextcloud_files() is optional and can be skipped ## if the data is provided in the `paths$raw_data_dir` files_pilot_b <- kwb.pilot::download_nextcloud_files(   dir_cloud = paths$b_cloud_raw,   dir_local = paths$b_local_raw )  if (length(files_pilot_b) > 0L) {      tsv_paths <- list.files(     path = paths$b_local_raw,     full.names = TRUE,     pattern = "xls$"   )      kwb.pilot::write_to_influxdb_loop(     tsv_paths = tsv_paths,     paths = list(       site_code = paths$b_site_code,       raw_data_dir = paths$b_local_raw     ),     changed_only = FALSE,     max_tsv_files = 5,     batch_size = 5000   )      ### Move all files for Pilot B`s cloud "raw" data directory to the "imported"    ### directory (in case that a file is already existing there: overwrite it)!   paths_pilot_b <- data.frame(     raw = file.path(paths$b_cloud_raw, files_pilot_b),     imported = file.path(paths$b_cloud_imported, files_pilot_b)   )      kwb.pilot::move_nextcloud_files(paths_pilot_b, overwrite = TRUE)    } else {      message(sprintf(     "Nothing to do for '%s'! No new files in '%s'",     paths$b_site_code,     paths$b_cloud_raw   )) }

what: Calculate operational parameters for Berlin-Friedrichshagen — calculate_operational_parameters_berlin_f
title: Calculate operational parameters for Berlin-Friedrichshagen — calculate_operational_parameters_berlin_f
text: Calculate operational parameters Berlin-Friedrichshagen

title: Calculate operational parameters for Berlin-Friedrichshagen — calculate_operational_parameters_berlin_f
code:
calculate_operational_parameters_berlin_f(   df,   calc_list = list(vfrPerm = "`Durchfluss_Rohwasser` - `Durchfluss_Konzentrat`", yield =     "100*(`Durchfluss_Rohwasser` - `Durchfluss_Konzentrat`) / `Durchfluss_Rohwasser`",     conLoop =     "(`Durchfluss_Rohwasser`*`LF_Rohwasser` + `Durchfluss_Rezirkulation`*`LF_Konzentrat`)/(`Durchfluss_Rohwasser` + `Durchfluss_Rezirkulation`)",     recovery = "100*(1 - `LF_Permeat` / conLoop)", deltaPreProcConc =     "`Druck_Arbeitsdruck` - `Druck_Konzentrat`", flux = "vfrPerm / (4 * 7.6)", cfv =     "(`Durchfluss_Rohwasser`+ `Durchfluss_Rezirkulation`) / ((pi * 0.0095^2) * 1000 * 3600)",           tmp = "((`Druck_Arbeitsdruck` + `Druck_Konzentrat`) / 2) - `Druck_Permeat`",     nwpt =     "normalised_permeate_flow(tempFeed = `Temperatur_Rohwasser`,
                                     conLoop = `conLoop`,
                                     vfrPerm = `vfrPerm`,
                                     vfrLoop = `Durchfluss_Rezirkulation`,
                                     vfrFeed = `Durchfluss_Rohwasser`,
                                     prePerm = `Druck_Permeat`,
                                     preProc = `Druck_Arbeitsdruck`,
                                     preConc = `Druck_Konzentrat`,
                                     nwp0 = 1.429162,
                                     vfrPerm0 = 800)",           nwpr = "- ((1 - (nwpt / vfrPerm))) * 100"),   calc_list_name = c("Durchfluss Permeat", "Ausbeute", "Leitfähigkeit Rezirkulation",     "Rückhalt", "Druckverlust (Feed - Konzentrat)", "Flux",     "Überströmungsgeschwindigkeit", "Transmembrandruck", "Normalisierter Permeatstrom",     "Relativer Permeatstrom"),   calc_list_unit = c("l/h", "%", "\xb5S/cm", "%", "bar", "l/h/m2", "m/s", "bar",     "l/h", "%"),   calc_paras = c("Durchfluss_Rohwasser", "Durchfluss_Konzentrat",     "Durchfluss_Rezirkulation", "Druck_Arbeitsdruck", "Druck_Rohwasser",     "Druck_Konzentrat", "Druck_Permeat", "LF_Permeat", "LF_Rohwasser", "LF_Konzentrat",     "Temperatur_Rohwasser") )

title: Helper Function: Download Nextcloud Files from a Directory — download_nextcloud_files
code: if (FALSE) { #1 Open RStudio and run usethis::edit_r_environ() #2 In the opened window add the required environment variables ### NEXTCLOUD_URL = "https://<replace-with-nextcloud-cloud-url>" ### NEXTCLOUD_USER = "<your-nextcloud-username>" # your username ### NEXTCLOUD_PASSWORD = "your-nextcloud-app-password" ### see details below #3 For creating <your-nextcloud-app-password>: #3.1 go to: https://replace-with-nextcloud-url/index.php/settings/user/security #3.2 scroll down to create new app password #3.3 select a name e.g. r-script and copy the token and replace your-nextcloud-app-password #4 Finally you need to restart Rstudio and proceed with the code below: paths_list <- list(site_code = "Pilot_A", common_path = "ultimate/raw_data_pilots/<site_code>/data", dir_cloud = "projects/<common_path>", dir_local = "C:/kwb/projects/<common_path>")  paths <- kwb.utils::resolve(paths_list) download_nextcloud_files(dir_cloud = paths$dir_cloud, dir_local = paths$dir_local, file_pattern = "Project\\.xls$" ) }
